children.name: useless b1
children.definition: uselessnot useful or effective in any way:
examples: the doctor concluded that further treatment would be useless.
useless for
the land is useless for growing crops.
jay’s car was 20 years old, and useless for anything but a short journey to the local shops.
it is useless to do sth
it was useless to complain.
completely/totally/absolutely uselessthe treatment is completely useless.
wholly/entirely uselessfrom his point of view qualifications are wholly useless.
virtually/almost/practically uselessthese flaws could make the software virtually useless in a business environment.
quite uselessbritish english(= completely useless )the vehicle proved quite useless on rocky ground.
pretty/fairly uselessthe book is pretty useless for today's students.
render something uselessshe has a debilitating condition which renders her legs virtually useless.
make something uselesssalt water flooded into the land making it useless for farming.
prove uselesspolice checkpoints proved useless at stopping the suicide bombers.
worse than useless(= not useful, and causing harm or problems)it would be worse than useless to try and complain about him.

children.name: be no use b2
children.definition: be (of) no use to be useless:
examples: this map’s no use -- it doesn’t show the minor roads.
i’m freezing, and these heaters are no use either.
be (of) no use to
all this information is of no use to me now. it’s too late.
be of no use for doing sth
it’s a great rifle -- but no use for shooting anything bigger than a rabbit.

children.name: have got no use for b2
children.definition: have got no use for uk if you have no use for sth, you do not want it or need it because you cannot use it for anything:
examples: you may as well stop giving me these magazines - i’ve got no use for them, and they just go straight in the bin.

children.name: unhelpful c1
children.definition: unhelpful not improving a difficult situation:
examples: the instructions were badly written and unhelpful.
i don't need any more of your unhelpful advice!

children.name: be no good b2
children.definition: be no good informal to be useless:
examples: these matches must have got wet -- they’re no good at all.
yeah, clancy’s bar is a lively place, but it’s no good if you just want a quiet drink with a friend.
be no good to
you’re no good to me if you can’t drive a car.
do you want these bike parts? they’re no good to me.
be no good for (doing) sth
these glasses are no good for champagne.
we found out that the vehicle was not much good for transporting heavy loads.

children.name: be no help b2
children.definition: be (of) no help/ not be any help/not be much help to not be helpful in a particular situation: không giúp ích gì
examples: johnny had drawn me a map, but that was no help.
seat belts are of no help at all in 30% of car accidents.
i looked at the departures screen, but that was no help because it was out of order.
be (of) no help to
it was the nicest thing she could think of to say, but it was really no help to me.
the follow-up seminar on women’s issues was of no help to me, so i left early.
be (of) no help in doing sth
in-store videos were of no help in identifying the criminals.
the phrase book wasn’t much help in carrying on a conversation

children.name: for nothing b2
children.definition: for nothing with no good result or for no purpose
examples: he queued for two hours and(all)for nothing - there were no seats left.
let us make sure that these brave men did not die for nothing.

children.name: not helpful a2
children.definition: not helpful
examples: he bought a book on relaxation techniques but it wasn’t very helpful.

children.name: when it is useless to try to persuade sb
it’s like talking to a brick wall
children.definition: alsomight as well talk to a brick wallbritish /ɪts laɪk ˌtɔːkɪŋ tʊ ə ˌbrɪk ˈwɔːl, maɪt əz wel ˌtɔːk tʊ ə ˌbrɪk ˈwɔːl/ spoken use this to say that it is useless to try to persuade someone or argue with them, because they will not listen to what you are saying:
examples: ▪ i wouldn’t bother arguing with francis -- it’s like talking to a brick wall.
▪ i told you i don’t want to go out again tonight -- honestly, i might just as well talk to a brick wall!

children.name: be wasting your breath
children.definition: /biː ˌweɪstɪŋ jɔːʳ ˈbreθ/  spoken use this to tell someone that there is no point in trying to argue with someone or persuade them about something because they will not change their opinion:
examples: ▪ it’s no good trying to make kit change her mind -- you’d just be wasting your breath.
▪ he’s wasting his breath. there’s no way they’re going to lend him the money.

children.name: till you’re blue in the face
children.definition: /tɪl jɔːʳ ˌbluː ɪn ðə ˈfeɪs/  spoken if you talk, argue etc with someonetill you’re blue in the face, you talk or argue with them for a very long time when it is pointless to do this because they will not listen or understand:
examples: ▪ you can argue till you’re blue in the face, but it won’t do you any good.
▪ politicians can claim until they are blue in the face that students have never had it so good, but the fact is, they cannot justify those claims.

children.name: actions or activities that are useless
pointless c1
children.definition: pointless if sb does something that is pointless, it does not seem to have any useful purpose and will not help anyone: vô ích
examples: the argument was completely pointless.
pointless drug testing on animals
a pointless exercisesth that you have to do that does not seem to have any purpose việc vô ích
we had to change the sheets daily, which always seemed to me to be a pointless exercise.
it is pointless doing sthuk
it’s pointless trying to speak to the manager -- she’s always too busy.
look, it’s pointless us both waiting here -- i’ll go and find a phone.
it is pointless to do sth
the company says it is pointless to compete in the air package holiday market.
simon was probably dead, and it was pointless to think he was coming back.
pointlessly[adv]
‘when...? how...?’ i stammered pointlessly. i already knew the answers.
pointlessness[u]
trevor began explaining the pointlessness of a classical education.

children.name: futile x
children.definition: futile actions that are futile are useless because they have no chance of being successful:
examples: prove futilewhen an attempt ends without being successful
their efforts proved futile(= did not have any success ).
a futile attempt/effort
she shut the door in a futile attempt to keep the smell out.
a futile attempt to save the paintings from the flames
my efforts to go back to sleep proved futile.
it is futile to do sth
it was futile to continue the negotiations.
futility[u]
wilfrid owen’s poems stress the absolute futility of war.
an exercise in futilitysomething that would be pointless to try doing
signing a trade agreement would be an exercise in futility.

children.name: useless b1
children.definition: useless  if an activity is useless, it does not achieve anything or does not help anyone:
examples: numerous studies show that dieting is useless and may even cause weight gain.
i had to remind myself that worrying is a useless activity.
it is useless to do sth
it was useless now to ask for help from my mother
he knew it was useless to pretend to be innocent.
it is useless doing sthuk
it’s useless trying to talk to you when you’ve had a drink.
i think it would be useless writing to the company -- they haven’t even returned my calls.

children.name: spoken: it is useless to do sth
it’s not worth it x
children.definition: it’s not worth it spoken say this when you think that sth sb wants to do is not important enough to spend any time or money on:
examples: don’t get angry. it’s not worth it.
‘you should have your car serviced.’ ‘it isn’t worth it. i hardly ever drive now.’

children.name: it won’t do you any good b2
children.definition: it won’t do you any good/ it won’t get you anywhere spoken say this when you think that someone will not be able to change a situation or persuade someone by doing something:
examples: worrying about the test won’t do you any good.
i don’t think this is getting us anywhere. can we change the subject?
flattery won’t get you anywhere -- i’m not doing it.
all this speculation isn’t doing anyone any good.
what's the good of...? / what good is ...?
what good is sitting alone in your room?

children.name: it’s no use b2
children.definition: it’s/there’s no usespoken/it’s/there’s no gooduk spoken  say this when something you are doing is not working so it is pointless to continue:
examples: no use (in) doing sth
it’s no use talking to me about interest rates and mortgages -- i find it all too confusing.
it’s no use lying about it because i saw you do it!
there’s no use in getting upset about it now.
be no good doing sthbritish
it’s no good sitting here feeling sorry for yourself.
there’s no good punishing him hours later, because he won’t remember what he’s done wrong.
what’s the use of...?/ what use is...?
try not to get depressed – after all, what's the use of worrying?

children.name: there’s no point b2
children.definition: there’s no point/what’s the point especially spoken say this when you think that it is useless to do sth because it will not achieve any useful purpose: vô ích thôi
examples: ‘why don’t you try and sort out your argument with mike?’ ‘there’s no point -- he never listens.’
don’t try working out what your exam results will be -- there’s no point.
there’s no point (in) doing sth
there’s no point kidding yourself, karen -- he just isn’t interested in you anymore.
it’s frustrating, but there’s no point in getting angry.
what’s the point of doing sth?spoken
you’ve already decided, so what’s the point of discussing it?
see no point/not see the point
i didn’t see the point of waiting around, so i left.
i figured i’d be in town a while, and i saw no point in making enemies when i didn’t have to.

children.name: be a waste of time b1
children.definition: be a waste of time/be wasting your time  spoken use this when you think that sb should not spend their time doing sth because it will definitely not achieve anything: tốn thời gian
examples: be a waste of time doing sth/wasting your time doing sth
you’re wasting your time trying to start that car. the battery’s completely flat.
i told you it would be a waste of time applying for a visa.
why waste your time trying to convince him? he won’t change his mind.

children.name: worthless c1
children.definition: worthless
examples: 1something that is worthless has no importance, or useopp valuable: vô dụng
the house was full of worthless junk.
the information was worthless to me.
2a worthless person has no good qualities or useful skillssyn useless: vô dụng
his parents had made him feel worthless.
she was criticized so much by her employers that she began to feel worthless.
worthlessness[u]
she struggled to overcome her feelings of worthlessness.
people who have been abused as children often experience feelings/a sense of worthlessness.

children.name: romantic c2
children.definition: romanticadjective
examples: slightly disapprovingnot practical and having a lot of ideas which are not related to real life
_she has a romanticideaof what it's like to be a struggling young artist.

children.name: water off a duck's back c2
children.definition: water off a duck's backmainly disapproving criticisms of or warnings to a particular person that haveno effect on that person : nước đổ đầu vịt
examples: i've told him that he's heading for trouble, but he doesn't listen-it's just water off a duck's back.

children.name: feeble c2
children.definition: feeble not very good or effectivesyn weak: yếu kém
examples: _a feeblejoke/excuse
a feeble excuse
a rather feeble committee

children.name: idle c2
children.definition: idle not serious, or not done with any definite intention : chẳng để làm gì
examples: she was not a woman to makeidle threats.
idle chatter/talk/gossip etc
it was only fromidle curiositythat she went into the barn.

children.name: pathetic c2
children.definition: pathetic disapproving making sb feel no respect, often because unsuccessful or showing no ability, effort or bravery : không thỏa đáng
examples: _a pathetic attempt/joke/excuse
_are you telling me you're frightened to speak to her? don't be so pathetic!

children.name: pitiful c2
children.definition: pitifuladjective
examples: describes something that you consider is bad or not satisfactory or not enough
a pitiful state of affairs
the amount of time and money being spent on researching this disease is pitiful.

children.name: be chasing your tail x
children.definition: be chasingyourtailto be busy doing a lot of things but achieving very little
